messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Acrobatics of ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯

Paper Abstract: Abstract One can fix the randomness used by a randomized algorithm, but there is no analogous notion of fixing the quantumness used by a quantum algorithm. Underscoring this fundamental difference, we show that, in the black-box setting, the behavior of quantum polynomial-time (ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯\mathsf{BQP}) can be remarkably decoupled from that of classical complexity classes like ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}. Specifically: â€¢ There exists an oracle relative to which ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯âŠ„ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–§not-subset-ofsuperscriptğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯superscriptğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–§\mathsf{NP}^{\mathsf{BQP}}\not\subset\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{PH}}, resolving a 2005 problem of Fortnow. As a corollary, there exists an oracle relative to which ğ–¯=ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{P}=\mathsf{NP} but ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯â‰ ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¬ğ– ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¬ğ– \mathsf{BQP}\neq\mathsf{QCMA}. â€¢ Conversely, there exists an oracle relative to which ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯âŠ„ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯not-subset-ofsuperscriptğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯superscriptğ–¯ğ–§ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{NP}}\not\subset\mathsf{PH}^{\mathsf{BQP}}. â€¢ Relative to a random oracle, ğ–¯ğ–¯=ğ–¯ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯\mathsf{PP}=\mathsf{PostBQP} is not contained in the â€œğ–°ğ–¬ğ– ğ–°ğ–¬ğ– \mathsf{QMA} hierarchyâ€ ğ–°ğ–¬ğ– ğ–°ğ–¬ğ– ğ–°ğ–¬ğ– â‹¯superscriptğ–°ğ–¬ğ– superscriptğ–°ğ–¬ğ– superscriptğ–°ğ–¬ğ– â‹¯\mathsf{QMA}^{\mathsf{QMA}^{\mathsf{QMA}^{\cdots}}}. â€¢ Relative to a random oracle, Î£k+1ğ–¯âŠ„ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯Î£kğ–¯not-subset-ofsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î£ğ‘˜1ğ–¯superscriptğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯superscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î£ğ‘˜ğ–¯\mathsf{\Sigma}_{k+1}^{\mathsf{P}}\not\subset\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{\Sigma}_{k}^{\mathsf{P}}} for every kğ‘˜k. â€¢ There exists an oracle relative to which ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯=ğ–¯#â€‹ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯superscriptğ–¯#ğ–¯\mathsf{BQP}=\mathsf{P^{\#P}} and yet ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–¯ğ–§\mathsf{PH} is infinite. (By contrast, relative to all oracles, if ğ–­ğ–¯âŠ†ğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}\subseteq\mathsf{BPP}, then ğ–¯ğ–§ğ–¯ğ–§\mathsf{PH} collapses.) â€¢ There exists an oracle relative to which ğ–¯=ğ–­ğ–¯â‰ ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯=ğ–¯#â€‹ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯superscriptğ–¯#ğ–¯\mathsf{P}=\mathsf{NP}\neq\mathsf{BQP}=\mathsf{P}^{\mathsf{\#P}}. To achieve these results, we build on the 2018 achievement by Raz and Tal of an oracle relative to which ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯âŠ„ğ–¯ğ–§not-subset-ofğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–§\mathsf{BQP}\not\subset\mathsf{PH}, and associated results about the Forrelation problem. We also introduce new tools that might be of independent interest. These include a â€œquantum-awareâ€ version of the random restriction method, a concentration theorem for the block sensitivity of ğ– ğ–¢ğŸ¢superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC^{0}} circuits, and a (provable) analogue of the Aaronson-Ambainis Conjecture for sparse oracles.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The computational complexity of linear optics",
        "The need for structure in quantum speedups",
        "Forrelation: A problem that optimally separates quantum from classical computing",
        "Quantum supremacy using a programmable superconducting processor",
        "Quantum computing, postselection, and probabilistic polynomial-time",
        "Quantum certificate complexity",
        "BQP and the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Complexity-Theoretic Foundations of Quantum Supremacy Experiments",
        "Complexity-Theoretic Limitations on Blind Delegated Quantum Computation",
        "A full characterization of quantum advice",
        "Quantum computability",
        "Two theorems on random polynomial time",
        "Quantum Lower Bounds for Approximate Counting via Laurent Polynomials",
        "Understanding quantum algorithms via query complexity",
        "Strengths and weaknesses of quantum computing",
        "On the complexity of quantum partition functions",
        "Non-deterministic exponential time has two-prover interactive protocols",
        "Error-bounded probabilistic computations between MA and AM",
        "Relativizations of the P=?NP question",
        "Does co-NP have short interactive proofs?",
        "Classical simulation of commuting quantum computations implies collapse of the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Circuit lower bounds collapse relativized complexity classes",
        "Quantum complexity theory",
        "Pulling out the quantumness [online]",
        "Complexity limitations on quantum computation",
        "Parity, circuits, and the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "A fast quantum mechanical algorithm for database search",
        "Quantum Generalizations of the Polynomial Hierarchy with Applications to QMA(2)",
        "Degree and sensitivity: tails of two distributions",
        "Computational Limitations of Small-Depth Circuits",
        "On relativized exponential and probabilistic complexity classes",
        "Threshold computation and cryptographic security",
        "An average-case depth hierarchy theorem for Boolean circuits",
        "Induced subgraphs of hypercubes and a proof of the sensitivity conjecture",
        "MIP*=RE",
        "A polynomial restriction lemma with applications",
        "Some connections between nonuniform and uniform complexity classes",
        "Quantum multi-prover interactive proof systems with limited prior entanglement",
        "Quantum Merlin-Arthur proof systems: Are multiple Merlins more helpful to Arthur?",
        "Quantum Pseudorandomness and Classical Complexity",
        "How hard is it to approximate the Jones polynomial?",
        "BPP and the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Constant depth circuits, Fourier transform, and learnability",
        "Some applications of hypercontractive inequalities in quantum information theory",
        "Polynomial Bounds for Decoupling, with Applications",
        "An entropy proof of the switching lemma and tight bounds on the decision-tree size of AC0",
        "On the power of quantum proofs",
        "Complexity theory column 89: The polynomial hierarchy, random oracles, and Boolean circuits",
        "Oracle separation of BQP and PH",
        "A classical leash for a quantum system: Command of quantum systems via rigidity of CHSH games",
        "IP = PSPACE",
        "Polynomial-time algorithms for prime factorization and discrete logarithms on a quantum computer",
        "On the power of quantum computation",
        "A complexity theoretic approach to randomness",
        "Vanishing-error approximate degree and QMA complexity",
        "The complexity of approximate counting",
        "Notes on switching lemmas",
        "PP is as hard as the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "A quantum polynomial hierarchy and a simple proof of Vyalyiâ€™s theorem",
        "Succinct quantum proofs for properties of finite groups",
        "Limits on the power of quantum statistical zero-knowledge",
        "Some consequences of non-uniform conditions on uniform classes",
        "Quantum computational advantage using photons"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Acrobatics of ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
